instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.A1990: What is A1990? A1990 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2018, 2019 with EMC3215, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01041, 820-01814..
definitions.ISL9240: What is ISL9240? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2018 through 2020.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.3V3_G3H_RTC: What is 3V3_G3H_RTC? 3V3_G3H_RTC Is an abbreviation of PP3V3_G3H_RTC which is one of the first rails that has to come on in order for the USB-C mux chip to be powered in the T2 chip Macbook Pros..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.820-1958: What is 820-1958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable
threads.message:
Hello,

I'm working on a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1990</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that does not turn on anymore. Charger is stuck at 5.19V (stable) on each of the 4 USB-C ports, power stays at 0.036A (+/-0.002A).

With the battery plugged in, logic board not taken out, I measured:
3.37V on the testpad <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL>
7.59V to 12.27 on the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, unstable.

With the battery unplugged, logic board not taken out, I measured:
40 to 160mV on the testpad <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL>
20mV for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> measured on <RESISTOR>R3451</RESISTOR>, pin2
17mV for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> measured on <CAPACITOR>C3503</CAPACITOR>, pin1
Then I checked <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R6968</RESISTOR>, pin1 and pin2. It reads a 200 to 400mV, fluctuating a lot. Might peaks very briefly at 1.x V, unless it's due to the autorange of the multimeter

There is no short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; red probe on pin1 of <CAPACITOR>C3503</CAPACITOR>, black probe on a screw shows 0.7 MOhm

Given the ~20mV of <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>, the value of <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> is not a surprise.

Page 68 shows <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> should give <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL>, which, on page 67, enables <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL>, whose value should be 3.38V.



Currently taking the logic board out of the case to measure what the <CHIP>ISL9240</CHIP> receives as inputs.



Background:
The defective logic board is in a MacBook that had its top case+keyboard+battery replaced at the Apple Store in May.
The logic board, in its current condition, could win a beauty contest.


Is there any way to make sure that the ISL 9240 is the culprit at 100% ?
I never had to unsolder such a chip so far. Wondering if I would be better off finding a rat lab to train myself before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable
threads.message:
Getting <SIGNAL>EN_MVR</SIGNAL> will not help you, until you get <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; it powers <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_RTC</SIGNAL> power supply.

Post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages, with charger alone (no battery); <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>CBC_ON</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable
threads.message:
Hi,
Sorry for the delay in posting the missing voltages; the idiots at the apple store messed up with the screws heads holding the logic board, I had to find an iron bit to get rid off several heads with a driller -_-

Out of the case, with just one pair of Thunderbolt ports plugged on it, the ampmeter reads 5.17V at 0.172A.
(Yesterday in the top case it was 5.19V at 0.036A)

My <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 0.00 mV measured on <CAPACITOR>C6582</CAPACITOR>, pin1

Regarding the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>) : 0 mV [COLOR=rgb(40, 50, 78)](<CAPACITOR>C7027</CAPACITOR> pin 1)[/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> : 0mV [COLOR=rgb(40, 50, 78)](<RESISTOR>R7015</RESISTOR> pin 2)[/COLOR]
<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> : 12.7mV
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> :
VDDA: 110mV (test pad & <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> pin1)
VDDP: 110mV (test pad)
<SIGNAL>CBC_ON</SIGNAL>:  could not find a way to measure this one
A MON: 20mV (<RESISTOR>R5439</RESISTOR> pin1)
B MON: 3mV (<RESISTOR>R5429</RESISTOR>)
_________

I plugged the charger cable into the other USB-C port, but part of the same pair. This time, the multimeter shows 5.17V, and it's fluctuating between 0.36 and 0.48A.
Moreover, I measured <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> again, on <RESISTOR>R4802</RESISTOR>, pin1, and it's cycling: 7.9V to 12.28V

________
I moved the same connector on the other side of the board. When plugged, one port shows 5.19V and 0.036A; the other one 5.14V and fluctuating between 0.36A and 0.48A
<SIGNAL>USB_C_XB_CC1_CONN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R3451</RESISTOR> pin 2 shows a cycling <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 7.9V to 12.28V
<SIGNAL>USB_C_XB_CC2_CONN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R3461</RESISTOR> pin 2 shows 0.0V
(when charger plugged in the relevant USB-C port, obviously)

Did the same test with the other pair of USB-Connector; plugged into each side of the logic board;
1 port shows 5.17V and fluctuating Amps (0.36-0.48), with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> cycling,
the second one is either stuck at 0.036A one one side, or at 0.172A the other side

<RESISTOR>R3452</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3462</RESISTOR> are good, 4.04 kOhms
<RESISTOR>R3451</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3461</RESISTOR> are good, 10.1kOhms
<RESISTOR>R3453</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R3463</RESISTOR> are good, 5.00 kOhms

________
Measurements taken again on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, but this time with the charger plugged on the USB-C port at 5.13V (0.36-0.48A)
Regarding the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL>) : 5.10 V (<CAPACITOR>C7027</CAPACITOR> pin 1)
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> : 120 to 300mV (<RESISTOR>R7015</RESISTOR> pin 2)
<SIGNAL>TP_CHGR_SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> : 37mV to 3.2V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL> : 0mV

VDDA: 5.16V (test pad & <RESISTOR>R7075</RESISTOR> pin1)
VDDP: 5.14V (test pad)
<SIGNAL>CBC_ON</SIGNAL>:  could not find a way to measure this one
A MON:   13 to 84mV (<RESISTOR>R5439</RESISTOR> pin1)
B MON:  1mV (<RESISTOR>R5429</RESISTOR>)

Currently reading [URL]https://logi.wiki/index.php/CD3215_Bootup_Sequence[/URL]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable
threads.message:
You must get same behavior on all USB-C ports.
If not, you have problems on USB-C areas.

Check and compare diode mode readings around <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips.
Start with their LDOs and CC1/2 lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable
threads.message:
I removed the UB300, cleaned the pad and reapplied solder, but the pad 91 seems gone. I can't re-apply solder on it. What's the best way to fix that?

I assume I will have to solder a tiny wire from pin 2 of DB529 to pin 91 of the new <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>.

But pin42 of JB500 seems a bit more problematic...It seems there is a trace from Pin 2 of DB529 to pin42 of JB500 though. So, would a wire from "pad 91" of UB300 to pin 2 of DB529 be enough ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable
threads.message:
There are 3 more USB ports to use.
I don't think someone really needs to connect the charger and 3 USB devices at same time.
And probably that port will also work when you flip the USB device connected.

If you want to fix it properly, check trace continuity and see which part need to rebuild.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable
threads.message:
I agree but ideally I'ld like to give back the device with 4 working USB-C port.
I blew away the ESD 8011 protection diodes DB504 and DB529:(

And LDO at 0.36V a little bit low

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable
threads.message:
Did you solder same termination code?
C00, A12, B03 are not compatible.

Did you compare again diode mode readings around the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips?
Do you get correct LDOs voltage on all of them?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable

LDO reading seems a bit high for PP1V1_UPC_{}_LDO_BMC and a bit low for PP3V3_UPC_{}_LDO

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-07 Stuck at 5.19V and 0.035A - <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> at 20mV - <SIGNAL>CHGR_EN_MVR</SIGNAL> unstable
threads.message:
Sorry for the quote, i must have missclicked.
WIll redo the job this evening and let you know. Thanks.

Edit: CB304 is now out of the board,it looks like I perhaps broke it while trying to measure <SIGNAL>1V1_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>. Can't solder it back in place.
I measured it, 1.12uF. If I can measure it, I don't understand why I can't put it back in place.

Edit: I found a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-1958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> (MAcBook Air 2020) donor board, took the <CAPACITOR>C2830</CAPACITOR>, schematics shows 2.2uF, measured it, 0.3nF...going to pick them all one by one and test as I do not have any 2018 MacBook Pro donor board
Might be luckier if I pick one on the same part of the circuitry xD

Edit: <CAPACITOR>C3206</CAPACITOR>, 1.03uF, but 6.3V; <CAPACITOR>C4423</CAPACITOR>, 2.1uF, 4V
Looks like I ripped off the pad of CB304, will scratch the surface to solder on the trace

I replaced the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>;

I didn't succeed, but I plugged the power, and I still get [email]5.19V@0.03A[/email] on 1 port on each side, and [email]5V@0.36A[/email] on the other. That's less than before actually.
